Best Practices in Cloud Computing: Designing for the Cloud Ruth Lennon Letterkenny Institute of Technology, 
Ireland Ruth.Lennon@LYIT.ie  Amir Zeid American University of Kuwait, Iraq Amir.Zeid@gmail.com  Lars 
Arne Skår Morten Udnæs Arne Jorgen Berre Miles Consulting, Miles Consulting, Sintef Norway Norway Norway 
Lars@miles.no Udnaes@miles.no Arne.j.berre@sintef.no Dumitru Roman Einar Landre Willem-Jan van den Heuvel 
STI, University of Innsbruck, StatoilHydro, European Research Institute in Austria Norway Services Science, 
dumitru.roman@sti2.at Einla@statoilhydro.com The Netherlands wjheuvel@uvt.nl  Abstract Cloud computing 
is the latest technology evolution and potential silver bullet, and there is both great expectation and 
fear to what consequences these technologies might cause. Based on the ex­perience with the lack of adoption 
of SOA among the general development community the recommendation is to make sure that the development 
community engage in how cloud computing evolves. Although there is already strong support for these tech­nologies 
from companies such as IBM and Microsoft, there is a need to explore good ways of designing services 
for the Cloud to ensure quality and productivity. There are movements in the mod­elling community that 
require further investigation as well as sur­viving concepts from the SOA era that need to be captured. 
In addition -due to the potential rapid availability of services in the cloud it is important to start 
exploring consequences of using such services, for instance access control, regulatory issues, develop­ment 
practices, security and practical operational issues. Captur­ing and discussing best practices on these 
subjects will contribute to a healthy movement in the right direction for those who will develop services 
for the Clouds. Categories and Subject Descriptors D.2.0 [Software Engineer­ing]]: general -standards. 
D.2.2 [Design tools and techniques], D.2.3. [Coding tools and techniques], D.2.5. Testing and debug­ging, 
D.2.6. Programming Environments, D.2.9 Management, D.2.11 Software Architectures, D.2.12 Interoperability, 
De.2.13 Reusable Software.. General Terms: Management, Performance, Design, Economics, Reliability, Security, 
Human Factors, Standardization, Legal As­pects. Keywords Cloud; SOA; Web Services; Service Orientation; 
SaaS. Copyright is held by the author/owner(s). OOPSLA 2009, October 25-29, 2009, Orlando, FL, USA. ACM 
978-1-60558-768-4/09/10. 1. Introduction In the field of Web Services interest has now turned towards 
Cloud computing and delivering Software As A Service. In con­trast to SOA, we are already starting to 
see widespread and suc­cessful use of cloud and software as a service. Thus, the concept of SOA while 
not delivering on its promises, resulted in an evolu­tion towards Cloud Computing and SAAS. We are starting 
to see reasons why the focus on services is important. This poster will outline the results of the related 
workshop. Due to the interactive nature of the workshop a number of ques­tions will be explored such 
as: Can Cloud Computing be used without the traditional clus­tered, high­availability and highly complicated 
software stacks from big vendors or high profile open source initiatives?  Is Cloud Computing a viable 
option for legacy mission critical backend system typically supported by mainframes?  Is Cloud Computing 
a suitable platform for government self services?  What impact will Cloud Computing have on other industries? 
 Will the move to Cloud based technologies strengthen the arguments put forward by Nicholas G. Carr 
that IT doesn t matter ?  Can Cloud Computing change the way we organize IT?  The workshop will focus 
on the design issues surrounding the cloud and will provide summary of the comments and conclusions reached 
during the workshop. The balance of industrial to educa­tional input in each issue will provide a more 
balanced view and should result in interesting new topics for further discussion:  2. Organizers There 
are multiple organizers of the workshop from industry and academia. Organizers include:. Ruth Lennon, 
Researcher & Lecturer in Letterkenny Institute of Technology, Ireland.  Lars Arne Skar, CTO of 
Miles Consulting based in Norway.  Morten Udnaes, Systems Architect, Miles Consulting, Norway.  Arne 
Berre, Chief Scientist in SINTEF ICT Research Unit.  Dr. Amir Zeid, is the program lead of Computer 
Science and Information Systems at the American University of Kuwait.  Dumitru Roman, Senior Researcher 
in Semantic Technology Institute, Innsbruck, Austria.  Einar Landre, is a practicing software professional 
with 25 years experience.  Prof. Dr. Willem­Jan van den Heuvel is the managing director of the European 
Research Institute of Services Science.  The organizers of the related workshop have produced this poster 
so as to provide a moderated and insightful summary of the views of the workshop participants.  3. Poster 
Format The poster will contain a number of sections which will outline what the participants expected 
from the workshop; the topics identified for discussion; survey results; participant comments; workshop 
conclusions and finally problems that were identified. Each section of the poster will include short 
terms or com­ments as made by the participants. These comments will be gath­ered by the organisers and 
organised in a coherent format for presentation. As with last years workshop we would expect some of 
the comments to be controversial. Often it is in the need to convert a utopian albeit intangible solution 
to something more concrete for the commercial world that provides the most interest­ing steps towards 
new thinking. 4. Questions: Designing for the Cloud Some of the more concrete questions that it is envisaged 
will be discussed in this poster include.: What patterns are appropriate for the modeling, design and 
analysis of Cloud Computing?  What are the important semantic aspects and ontologies for services in 
the Cloud.  Can we design the Cloud to avoid vendor lock­in?  How can we design to alleviate security 
fears in the Cloud?  How can SoaML be applied to reduce the risk of failure of rapid development of 
Cloud applications.  5. Comments The use of adaptable resources on a plug-n-play, or plug-n-pay, basis 
promotes scalability if and when needed. The reduction in the requirement to purchase hardware in this 
time of recession has not gone unnoticed by many large companies. The ability to scale up and down as 
necessary with reduced overhead is advantageous to even the smallest of enterprises. Thus the design 
of the system must enable flexible and efficient delivery of services on dynamic and often ad-hoc basis. 
Work on evaluating the need for and abil­ity of cloud computing has been discussed in [2]. Further work 
on the appropriate design of cloud systems will alleviate many of the problems they have discussed. It 
is anticipated that the poster will contain many comments by experienced cloud developers outlin­ing 
the most significant issues that they have had to deal with. 6. Summary A workshop on the design of 
cloud using established and indeed innovative best practice techniques will explore the practical is­sues 
involved in the design of enterprise scale systems. The issues identified by the workshop will be presented 
in a poster which will be available online as well as being displayed at OOPSLA 2009. The results of 
the workshop will be published on https://wiki.miles.no/display/EXT/oopsla09_cloud_computing.  References 
[1] unknown author, SOA is dead; long live Services, aps­blog.burtongroup.com/2009/01/soa-is-dead-long-live-services.html 
[2] Napper, Jeffrey, Bientinesi, Paolo, Can Cloud Computing Reach the Top 500?, UCHPC-MAW 09, May 18-20, 
2009, Ischia, Italy.
